awd_titl_txt: Search for Neutrinoless Double Beta Decay with Nemo-3 and Super-Nemo Experiments
awd_abstract_narration:
Neutrinos are fascinating elementary particles and understanding their characteristics may explain why there is more matter than anti-matter in the universe.  Neutrinos have very small mass and zero electric charge so they could be their own anti-particle, and that is their key to unlocking the matter vs anti-matter content of the universe.  This award focuses on determining if neutrinos are their own anti-particles using the NEMO-3 and SuperNEMO experiments developed by the Neutrino Ettore Majorana Observatory (NEMO) collaboration.  A prototype of the SuperNEMO design will be commissioned soon, and this award will support the research of a graduate student who will earn his dissertation using the newly commissioned equipment.  The research will include background analysis, energy resolution improvements, and a search for neutrinoless double beta decay.  The student will develop highly technical skills that will allow him to contribute to STEM fields.   

The NEMO-3 experiment collected data by employing about 10 kg of thin isotopic foils surrounded by a wire drift chamber for 3D particle tracking in a 25 G magnetic field and scintillator blocks to measure the energy of electrons.  This unique technique provides several observables for each registered event, offering a powerful means to identify double beta decays and to reject background processes.  SuperNEMO will further exploit the NEMO-3 technique.  The goal of SuperNEMO is to use 100 kg of Se-82 or some other isotope to probe the half-life for neutrinoless double beta decay at the level of 1x10^(26) years in a 500kg*year exposure, corresponding to the effective neutrino mass in the 50 meV range.  The research supported by this award will include the commissioning of the first SuperNEMO module.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The NSF grant PHY-1811901 supported our research group in the Department of Physics at the University of Texas at Austin in an experimental program focused on the search for never observed nuclear transition ? neutrinoless double beta decay ? which, if discovered, would determine that neutrinos are the same particles as their antimatter counterparts ? antineutrinos. If such a transition is detected, it would demonstrate that the most copious known elementary particles in Nature (on average there are about 330 neutrinos in each cubic centimeter in the Universe) have unique properties that may have significant impact for our better understanding of the matter-antimatter asymmetry in the presently observed Universe. Such a process would also provide the best direct measurements or constraints for the mass of neutrinos which is also currently unknown. If neutrinos are indeed involved in such transitions (i.e., if they are so called Majorana-type particles), they would help to significantly advance our knowledge of the theory of nuclear physics and elementary particles and the role of neutrinos in the early evolution of the Universe.

Our research team participated in two subatomic experiments that have been at the forefront of a worldwide program. We are members of the NEMO Collaboration - an international group of scientists from France, UK, Russia, Czech Republic, Slovakia, and the US that has built and operated the NEMO-3 detector and is now commissioning a larger replacement and follow-on experiment called SuperNEMO. Both experiments have been hosted in the Modane Underground Laboratory in the Frejus Tunnel under the French-Italian Alps. The detectors adopted a unique technique of observing the neutrinoless double beta decay by measuring two electrons in the final state using gas tracking chambers and large scintillator blocks. This approach allows to observe the trajectories and measure energies of electrons so the method is also capable of suppressing the omni-present natural radioactivity emitted from materials used to build the detector or coming from the surrounding environment.

We used the NEMO-3 data from decays of seven isotopes to conduct the search for the neutrinoless double beta transitions and for all of them reached the best precision to date. The values of measured half-lives are about billion times longer than the age of the Universe and constitute some of the rarest phenomena in physics.  No evidence for double beat transition without neutrinos has been observed. This allows to set stringent bounds on the neutrino mass - an important property of particle physics and cosmology.

 Our research group involved young researchers, graduate and undergraduate students, who have made significant and visible impact on many aspects of the experiments during their various phases and received excellent and versatile professional training. Most recently, we have delivered and commissioned two calibration systems that are essential for commissioning the SuperNEMO experiment and during  its long-term operations. These systems are documented in a Ph.D. dissertation of one of our graduate students.
